awd_titl_txt: DDRIG: Governance of Athletes through Protective Policies
awd_abstract_narration:
A range of protective policies have been implemented in the governance of sport based upon scientific and cultural understandings of biological-based differences. These protective policies include eligibility regulations and consensus statements on athletes’ health. They all depend upon social and cultural understandings of protection, and who needs protection and why. This project analyzes how protection is conceptualized across organizations, policies, and practice.  Project findings will translate beyond the sporting realm to enhance our understanding of how science and society intersect to shape dominant ways of knowing. This project will yield crucial insights into how protective policies enact a range of measures to safeguard selected notions of bodies through regulation, discipline, and/or exclusion. It will be of interest to athletes, coaches, policy makers, and administrators.

Focusing on the International Olympic Committee’s (IOC) consensus statement on relative energy deficiency in sport, or RED-S, as a case study, this project uses policy, bibliometric, and interview data to answer two central research questions: (1) how do scientists, policymakers, and other stakeholders involved with RED-S research and policy-creation identify bodies as (not) needing protection? And (2) what types of solutions to RED-S are proposed by scientists, policymakers, and other stakeholders involved with RED-S research and policy-creation? Drawing on theoretical insights from governmentality studies, the project contributes to larger discussions about the significance of social and/or biological dimensions in defining eligible bodies. This project produces further theoretical insights for science and technology scholars into rationales and strategies of governance that impact individuals, communities, and nations. Project findings will encourage transdisciplinary dialogue about how athlete’s bodies are regulated and policed, inside, and outside of sport, and inform future efforts to create inclusive and empathetic protective policies for athletes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project investigated how scientists, academics, and policymakers (selectively) interpret, qualify, and translate scientific evidence to create and implement protective policies or guidelines, specifically in the case of relative energy deficiency in sport (RED-S). Through this aim, this project looked to understand how constructions of sex and gender inform determinations of “problematic” bodies, or which bodies are needing (or deserving) of protection, and solutions to implementing “protection.” RED-S was specifically chosen as a case study given its illuminating and seemingly contradictory approach to women’s bodies, namely, the role of sociocultural and biological factors in the syndrome’s development, along with prevention, diagnosis, and treatment strategies.  

This qualitative project drew on semi-structured interviews conducted with scientists, physicians, and researchers involved with drafting and implementing the International Olympic Committee’s consensus statements on RED-S in order to: (1) examine how scientists, academics, and policymakers (selectively) interpret, qualify, and translate scientific evidence to create and implement policies, specifically in the case of relative energy deficiency in sport (RED-S), and (2) understand how constructions of sex and gender inform determinations of “problematic” bodies, or which bodies are needing (or deserving) of protection, and solutions to implementing “protection.” With the support of the award, a total of 12 interviews with scientists, physicians, academics, and researchers involved with writing the IOCCSR and/or RED-S related research were conducted and transcribed. Interview transcripts were analyzed, alongside three published IOC consensus statements on RED-S from the IOC during the award period.

Research findings have been presented at the annual meeting of the North American Society for the Sociology of Sport, with plans to present at the annual American College of Sport Medicine conference and the IOC’s World Conference on Prevention of Injury and Illness in Sport.

There are currently three papers in development that draw on the data collected and analyzed with the support of the award. The first looks to contribute to science and technology studies (STS) scholarship by complicating how ‘risk’ functions as a technique of governance in sporting contexts. The second paper is intended to benefit sport medicine researchers and personnel by providing specific policy recommendations to help develop more comprehensive approaches to RED-S and broader (athlete) health concerns at multiple levels of sport (i.e., elite, collegiate, and youth). The third paper examines how expert knowledge is translated into policy texts, specifically around defining and understanding “protection,” and how/under what contexts particular ways of knowing (i.e., sociocultural knowledges, medical or scientific knowledges) are interpreted and incorporated into document/policy texts.

In all, the project aims to encourage transdisciplinary dialogue about how women’s bodies are regulated and policed, as well as informing future efforts to create inclusive and comprehensive policies to protect (women) athletes. In particular, (athlete) health, more broadly, and RED-S, more specifically, is comprised of a heterogenous and complex array of social, political, cultural, and biological qualities and considerations. As such, topics around protection and safety for athletes, as well as general population(s), require diverse and multidisciplinary/transdisciplinary approaches, particularly for policies and other modalities of governance (e.g., consensus statements, guidelines). While the empirical site for this project is elite sport, its broader methodological and theoretical contributions, alongside its findings, have the potential to benefit research and policymaking efforts in other areas that engage questions of gender, science, and governance (e.g., abortion, gender-affirming care).
